content: The "Tax Credits for Jobs Now Act of 2012" is a new law that introduces a credit for increasing employment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Tax Credits for Jobs Now Act of 2012" introduces a credit for increasing employment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for 60% of the excess of wages paid in 2012 over 2011, and 40% of the excess of wages paid in 2013 over inflation-adjusted wages in 2012. The maximum credit for any employer in a calendar year is $500,000. The Tax Credits for Jobs Now Act of 2012 introduces a credit for increasing employment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for a minimum of 50% of specified amounts to be taken into account as wages, with a maximum credit not exceeding a certain amount based on wage increases. The term 'wages' in the Tax Credits for Jobs Now Act of 2012 is defined as specified in section 3306(b), with rules similar to section 51(h) applying for railway and agricultural labor. 'Inflation-adjusted wages' refer to aggregate wages paid in 2012 adjusted for inflation based on the cost-of-living adjustment for that year. "For purposes of applying this section for any calendar year ending after such disposition, the amount of wages deemed paid by the employer during periods before such disposition shall be decreased by wages attributable to the trade or business. If an individual has net earnings from self-employment in 2011 or 2012 and becomes an employee of the same trade or business in the following year, the credit allowable will be determined accordingly." "For purposes of determining the credit allowable for a taxable year beginning in a succeeding calendar year, the employer's aggregate wages for 2011 or 2012 shall be increased by an amount equal to the net earnings not exceeding the median household income in the United States for the respective year. Certain rules regarding trade or business employment, related individuals, and successor employers apply for this section." The text discusses amendments to the tax code related to employer credits, including rules for successor employers and denial of double benefits. Conforming amendments are also made to related sections of the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011.
